refnamediv.refpurpose: brief tutorial on writing Idol plugins

refsect1.title: Introduction
refsect1.para: Idol is extensible by means of small, dynamically-loadable plugins, which add functionality wanted by some but not others.

refsect2.title: Locations
refsect2.para: Idol plugins can either be installed in the system path (e.g. /usr/lib/idol/plugins/), or in a user's home directory (e.g. ~/.local/share/idol/plugins/). In either case, each plugin resides in a subdirectory named after the plugin itself.

In addition, each plugin needs a .idol-plugin index file, residing inside the plugin directory. This gives the code name of the plugin, as well as some metadata about the plugin such as its human-readable name, description and author.

example.title: Example Plugin Directory
example.para:
A system-installed plugin called subtitle-downloader would reside in /usr/lib/idol/plugins/subtitle-downloader, and would (at a minimum) have the following files:
subtitle-downloader.idol-plugin libsubtitle-downloader.so
If installed in a user's home directory, it would reside in ~/.local/share/idol/plugins/subtitle-downloader and have the same files.

refsect2.title: The .idol-plugin File
refsect2.para: The file should use the following template: [Idol Plugin] Module=plugin-name IAge=plugin interface age (starting at 1) Builtin=true or false Name=Human-Readable Plugin Name Description=Simple sentence describing the plugin's functionality. Authors=Plugin Author Name Copyright=Copyright Â© year Copyright Holder Website=http://plugin/website/ Most of the values in the template are fairly self-explanatory. One thing to note is that the plugin name should be in lowercase, and contain no spaces. The plugin interface age should start at 1, and only be incremented when the binary interface of the plugin (as used by Idol) changes. If the plugin does not have its own website, Idol's website (http://projects.mate.org/idol/) can be used.
The library file containing the plugin's code should be named libplugin-name.so (for C, or other compiled-language, plugins) or plugin-name.py (for Python plugins).

refsect2.title: Writing a Plugin
refsect2.para: Once resources have been created, and the plugin has been connected to Idol's UI in the impl_activate function, the plugin is free to go about its tasks as appropriate. If the user deactivates the plugin, or Idol decides to deactivate it, the impl_deactivate will be called. The plugin should free any resources grabbed or allocated in the impl_activate function, and remove itself from the Idol interface.

Note that plugins can be activated and deactivated (e.g. from Idol's plugin manager) many times during one Idol session, so the impl_activate and impl_deactivate functions must be able to cope with this.

Any of the API documented in the rest of the Idol API reference can be used by plugins, though the bindings for Python plugins are incomplete. Otherwise, Python plugins are written in the same way as C plugins, and are similarly implemented as classes derived from IdolPlugin.
